name: Port Sulphur
comments: A Creeping Bent studio collective project.

name: Blue Seven
comments: Jazz trio based in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Members are Joseph Cappello on piano, Kevin Gardner on bass and Peter Gaudioso on drums.

name: Royce Morgan
comments: Country and rockabilly singer, songwriter and guitarist from Kentucky. He also owned the short-lived (1959-1960) regional label, Royce Records, based in Central City, Kentucky.

name: Billy Harlan
comments: Country and rockabilly singer, songwriter and bass player from Kentucky.

name: Bob King [CA2]
aliases: Bob King featuring The Bob King Singers
comments: Singer, songwriter, family entertainer and a certified teacher who primarily performs music for children.  King's show for elementary school students is a combination of music, theatre, humour and principles of character education and positive youth development.

name: Amy King
comments: Singer, dancer and musician from Vancouver.

name: Vicky Simms
comments: Rock and roll singer from La Perouse, New South Wales.

name: Marty Cerf
comments: Songwriter, music publicist and founder of Phonograph Record Magazine

name: Blue Eyed Grass
comments: Delnora Reed and Jayron Weaver, the Nashville-based members of Blue Eyed Grass, describe themselves as a “new-grass” duo, with country roots and a modern bluegrass influence.

name: The Schneider Sisters
comments: Vocal/instrumental/variety duo consisting of sisters, Mary and Rita Schneider. They were known for their yodeling. On some of their early records, Mary played accordion and Rita played guitar. Mary died in 2009.

name: Foxxjazell
comments: Transgender Hip Hop artist from Birmingham Alabama

name: Lynne Sherman
comments: Big band vocalist, who worked with the orchestra's of Sonny Burke and Count Basie in the 1940s

name: Russ Taff
comments: Grammy & Dove Award winning singer and songwriter

name: Jimmy Swaggart
aliases: Jimmy Swaggart and His Golden Gospel Piano
comments: Televangelist and preacher from Ferriday, Louisiana. He also cashes in on marketing recordings of his cermons and music performances.

name: Harold Austin
comments: Bluegrass singer and guitarist from Sharon, Pennsylvania.

name: The Dixie Echoes
comments: Professional Southern Gospel band based in Pensacola

name: Jean and Lee Schilling
comments: Folk duo playing Appalachian mountain music

name: Ken Turner
comments: Gospel singer and songwriter best known for his ability to hit extremely low notes

name: Joel Cummins
comments: Keyboardist born in La Grange, Illinois

name: The Suades
comments: The Suades were a rock and roll band formed in Iowa in the summer of 1958 by Wayne Cooper [vocals/lead guitar] and Dick O'Neal [vocals/bass]. Other members of the original group included Randy Larson [piano/trumpet], R.J. Meyers [drums] and Rosie Stevens [vocals/gutar/bass]. They disbanded in 1963.

name: The Other Ones
comments: Formed in 1997 by Grateful Dead members and including changing members on various tours. The Other Ones, whose band name refers to the same titled GD song , only released one regular album. Upon reforming in 2003 and adding new members, the name was changed to The Dead.

name: Max Lipscomb
comments: Rock 'n' roll singer, guitarist and pianist

name: Keith Daniels
aliases: Keith Daniels & The Blue Ridge Ramblers
comments: Bluegrass musician who played fiddle with the Stevens Brothers. In 1958 he formed his own band, the "Blue Ridge Ramblers" which initiKeith Daniles and Del McCroury]]ally included Del McCoury.

name: The Heights
comments: Fictional band based on the short-lived TV series of the name.

name: Pekka Tiilikainen
comments: Radio reporter, author, lyricist and sometimes performer. In 1957 he recorded a duet with Tiikerinmetsästys in a humorist work "Älkää ampuko pianistia" , which translates into "Don't shoot the pianoplayer".

name: Three Days Wait
comments: Christian rock band based in Ohio

name: Walter Barnes
aliases: Walter Barnes and His Royal Creolians
comments: Musician (clarinet and saxophone) and bandleader based in Chicago, who extensively toured in the South of the US. On April 23, 1940, Barnes and eight members of his band along with 193 other people were killed in a fire at the Rhythm Night Club in Natchez, Mississippi.

name: Harmonica Frank
comments: Harmonica Frank Floyd was an itinerant medicine show and carnival performer playing harmonica and guitar while singing. He recorded for Chess and Sun in the 1950s.

name: Lee Gunness
aliases: Lee Gunness and the Eclipse Alley Heavenly Seven

name: Charlie Shoemake
comments: Jazz vibraphonist born in Houston, Texas

name: Al Johnson [US1]
comments: Rhythm and blues and soul singer and songwriter

name: Living
aliases: The Living Strings and The Living Voices
The Living Strings Plus Two Pianos
Living Trio with Chimes and Bells
comments: Easy listening studio musicians with fluctuating members that recorded for RCA Victor's budget label

name: Tim O'Neill
comments: Solo pianist who plays with his brother Ryan as The O'Neill Brothers

name: Cow Bop
comments: Cowboy jazz and western bebop band founded in 2003 by Bruce Forman. Members include Bruce Forman [guitar], Bruce's wife, Pinto Pammy [vocal], David Wise [sax, trumpet], Alex Frank [bass] and Jake Reed [drums].

name: Colin Cook
comments: Rock 'n' roll and pop singer. Born in Bangladesh, but migrated to Australia at the age of ten.

name: Jimmy Hannan
comments: Variety and game show host, singer and entertainer

name: The Ran-Dells
comments: Short-lived rock n roll band from New Jersey

name: Tim Reynolds [session]
comments: "Budget" artist related to PPX/PPX Productions. Anonymous studio vocalist specialized in sound-alike covers for the Twin Hits record label.

name: Anthony Field
comments: Australian musician, actor, songwriter and producer.

name: Murray Cook
comments: One of the founding members of the children's band The Wiggles and known as the Red Wiggle, who provided guitar, vocals and songwriting in the group He still serves as a songwriter and occasional guest on the group's albums.

name: Jeff Fatt
comments: Musician and actor and a member of the children's group The Wiggles. He was the son of Chinese parents, who owned a large retail store in Casino, New South Wales.

name: Arvell Shaw
aliases: Arvell Shaw and the Louis Armstrong Legacy Band
comments: Jazz bassist and sometime vocalist.  Shaw worked regularly as a touring musician with Louis Armstrong from 1947 until Armstrong's death.

name: David Ede
aliases: David Ede and The Rabin Band

name: Bernard Bresslaw
comments: Comedian and actor, who was featured in 14 of the British "Carry On" movie series

name: Yasuaki Shimizu
comments: Saxophonist, composer, arranger and producer.  Shimizu plays western classical and jazz.  His name in his native characters is 清水靖晃.

name: Frank Lacy
aliases: Frank Lacy + The Smalls Legacy Band ‎
comments: Jazz trombonist, especially associated with avant-garde jazz.  Lacy also occasionally sings.

name: Steve Spurgin
comments: Country and bluegrass singer-songwriter born in McKinney, Texas

name: Ric Slagle
comments: Blues and jazz saxophonist and singer.

name: Chick Rains
comments: Country music singer-songwriter, musician and producer born in Muskogee, Oklahoma

name: Pino Vinci
aliases: Pino Vinci e il suo complesso

name: Five Thousand Voices
comments: The combined congregations of various London Welsh churches and chapels.

name: Russell "Big Chief" Moore
aliases: Russell "Big Chief" Moore's Pow Wow Jazz Band

name: Rhos Male Voice Choir
comments: Choir from the mining village of Rhosllanerchrugog, near Wrexham, established 1891.

name: Rainy City Stompers
comments: Dixieland band that is a musical institution in Schleswig-Holstein, having been founded in 1956.

name: Junie McCree
comments: Lyricist, best known in music for vaudeville songs and performances. Also successful joke and sketch writer.

name: "That Girl" Quartet
comments: One of the first female vocal groups to record. Members included Harriet Keys, Allie Thomas, Precis Thompson, and Helen Summers.

name: New Church
comments: Not a formal band, but a short-lived loose amalgam of musicians

name: Wrap
comments: Jazz ensemble: Barbara Wiernik, Jean-Louis Rassinfosse, Alain Pierre.

name: The Avons [GB]
comments: Harmonic vocal trio, consisting of sisters in law Elaine and Valerie Murtagh, together with Raymond S Adams. They had previously been 'The Avon Sisters' before recruiting Ray in 1959 and shortening their name.

name: Ann Jones
aliases: Ann Jones and Her Western Sweethearts
comments: Born in Kansas and raised in Anaheim, California, Ann Jones was a Western music singer and songwriter.

name: The Four Winds
aliases: The Four Winds with Their Teenaged Friends

name: Ty Garner
comments: Blues singer and guitarist, mainly active on the European continent

name: The Time Beings
comments: Garage rock band from Chelmsford, Massachusetts

name: David Peel
aliases: David Peel And The Lower East Side
David Peel & The Lower East Side
comments: New York City based musician who first recorded in the late 1960s. His raw, acoustic "street rock" with lyrics about marijuana and "bad cops" appealed mostly to hippies.

name: Rex Pluto
comments: R&B/rock band formed in Worcester, MA.

name: Henri Bource
comments: Sax and flute player, who was born in the Netherlands, but came to Australia in 1954.

name: Ray Ellington
comments: Singer, bandleader and drummer from London. After seeing Duke Ellington perform in 1933, Henry Brown changed his name to Ray Ellington. He formed the bebop influenced comedic jazz group, the Ray Ellington Quartet in 1947.

name: Don Howard [US1]
comments: Don Howard Kaplow was a 17 year old high school student in Cleveland when he had his one big hit, "Oh Happy Day."

name: Nancy Binns Reed
comments: Composer of songs, musicals and operas.

name: Tony Randall
comments: Actor, director and producer known for his many roles in television and movies.

name: TNT Tribble
comments: R&B drummer and band leader from Pennsylvania.

name: Harry Clark
comments: Actor born in New York City, New York

name: Jack Diamond
comments: Vocalist in musicals on Broadway in the late 1940s

name: James Whitmore
comments: Dramatic actor with extensive credits in film, television and on stage.

name: Harold Lang
comments: Dancer and singer-actor, who was a cast member of the Cole Poter Broadway musical Kiss Me Kate from December 30, 1948 - July 28, 1950 where he played the part of Bill Lilling (Stage Doorman).

name: Kathryn Grayson
comments: Actress and operatic soprano. She had many roles in movie musicals in the 1940s through the 1950s.

name: John O'Hara
aliases: John O'Hara and the Famous O'Hara's Playboys
John O'Hara and His New Playboys
John O'Hara and "The Famous" O'Hara's Playboys

name: Audrey Arno
comments: Vocalist whose biggest success were achieved in France

name: Irma Schultz
comments: Pop singer, pianist and actress. During her marriage to drummer Nino Keller adding his family name to hers.

name: Rob'n'Raz
comments: Music duo consisting of Robert Wåtz and Rasmus Lindwall

name: DLC
comments: DLC stands for D-Flex, Lutricia McNeal Combination

name: Trooper
comments: Rock band from the Vancouver area

name: The Twigs
comments: Los Angeles-based alternative pop duo from Chicago formed by twin sisters, songwriters and singers Linda and Laura Good

name: Speed
comments: Punk band from Portadown, Northern Ireland

name: Loy Gordon
aliases: Loy Gordon and His Pleasant Valley Boys
comments: Country music performer based in Ohio.

name: Yahel
comments: DJ and producer, known for his melodic trance style

name: Dieter Dierks
comments: Producer of Ash Ra Tempel, Tangerine Dream, Scorpions. Founder of Dierks Studios in Cologne

name: Ozie Waters
comments: Ozie Waters was a Western singer, performer, songwriter and actor from Missouri

name: The Plainsmen
comments: Western vocal harmony and instrumental group. Members included Andy Parker, rhythm guitar Joaquin Murphy, steel guitar George Morgan, electric guitar Hank Caldwell, bass, vocals George Bambi, accordion

name: Dean Perrett
comments: Country music singer and cattleman from Queensland.

name: The Little Angels National Folk Ballet of Korea
comments: Dance and chorale youth group founded by Sun Myung Moon.

name: Jimmy Nail
comments: Actor and singer, famous for his rugged looks, hit singles and a strong Newcastle accent

name: John Townsend
comments: Blues and R&B singer and songwriter.

name: Inga Sulin
comments: Singer and actress from Luopioinen in southern Finland.

name: Montague Ewing
comments: Composer of light music including novelty songs.

name: 1 Plus 1
comments: A concept group created by Bobby Orlando

name: Sluts for Hire
comments: American alternative rock band based in Los Angeles, California.

name: Cora Vaucaire
comments: Chanteuse nicknamed "La Dame Blanche de Saint-Germain-des-Prés".

name: Oscar Castro-Neves
aliases: Oscar Castro Neves e Seu Conjunto

name: Micky Dolenz
comments: Actor, musician, television director, radio personality and theater director, best known as the drummer and principal lead singer of the 1960s pop/rock band The Monkees.

name: Sonny Clark
comments: Jazz pianist who mostly played hard bop

name: Barry Goldberg
comments: Blues and rock keyboardist, songwriter and record producer

name: Wilbur Harden
comments: American jazz trumpeter and flugelhorn player.

name: James Darren
comments: Television and film actor, best known for his signature role in the 1959 movie "Gidget” about the California surf culture, television director, and (teen) pop singer

name: John Boles
comments: Actor, who started out in Hollywood in silent movies, but became a huge star with the advent of talkies. After the First World War Boles moved to New York to study music. He quickly became well known for his talents and was selected to replace the leading man in the 1923 Broadway musical "Little Jesse James". He became an established star on Broadway and attracted the attention of Hollywood producers and actors. He is furthermore known for playing "Victor Moritz" in the 1931 film Frankenstein.

name: Louis Alter
comments: Pianist, composer and songwriter from New York City. Inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame in 1975.

name: Johnny Hodges
aliases: Johnny Hodges and The Ellington All-Stars Without Duke
Johnny Hodges and Orchestra (An Ellington Unit)
comments: Swing and mainstream jazz alto and soprano saxophonist.  Hodges was a longtime soloist with the Duke Ellington organization.

name: María Grever
personal_name: María Joaquina de la Portilla Torres
comments: Musician and composer, primarily of boleros

name: Stanley Adams
comments: Lyricist and songwriter. He wrote the English lyrics for the song What a Diff'rence a Day Made and the English lyrics for La cucaracha Adams was the president of the "American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers" (ASCAP) between 1953 and 1956 and again from 1959 until 1980.

name: Enrique Granados
personal_name: Pantaléon Enrique Costanzo Granados y Campiña

name: Sunny Skylar
aliases: Sunny Skylar and The Dianaze Orchestra
comments: Composer, singer, lyricist, and music publisher from Brooklyn, New York

name: Andy Russell
comments: Singer originally from Los Angeles, who was popular in the United States and Latin America

name: Denise Perrier
comments: Jazz singer based in San Francisco

name: Chris Potter
comments: Jazz multi-instrumentalist who pays various sasophones, clarinets, and flutes.  Potter is also a composer.

name: Fish Heads & Rice
comments: Members: Gary Talley, David James, Walter Ferguson, Stuart Brower.

name: Joe Haywood
comments: Soul music singer and drummer from Spartanburg, South Carolina

name: Dee Felice
aliases: Dee Felice and the Sleep Cat Band

name: Chris Stainton
comments: Keyboard player, session musician and songwriter

name: Pye Dubois
comments: Lyricist and poet. He was a frequent collaborator with Rush, Max Webster and Kim Mitchell.

name: The James Gang
aliases: The James Gang featuring The Dunn Chorus
comments: Funky blues rock. The band was formed in 1966 by drummer Jim Fox and bassist Tom Kriss, but only took off three years later after the inclusion of guitarist Joe Walsh.

name: Upp
comments: Rock-jazz fusion band, active in the 1970s

name: Tin Machine
comments: American hard rock band fronted by British US resident David Bowie

name: The Pretty Things
comments: Rhythm & blues and beat band from London

name: Nicky Crouch
comments: Guitarist, and vocalist. He has been in skiffle to beat and blues bands.

name: Jim Ingram
comments: Self-taught musician, newspaper columnist and reporter, and radio DJ and newsman from Detroit, Michigan.

name: Pierre Bachelet
comments: Singer, songwriter and film score composer

name: Czeslaw Niemen
comments: Born near Nowgorod (these days Belarus), Niemen became Poland's both in his motherland and internationally probably most acknowledged keyboarder, composer and bandleader. Also a writer. Starting as a beat musician and supporting Marlene Dietrich at her Warsaw concert in 1964, he - throughout his career - increasingly turned towards complex Art Rock, psychedelic sounds, electronics, classical music and Jazz. Nieman hardly ever did cover versions. He died of cancer.

name: Pearls Before Swine
comments: Psychedelic folk band formed by Tom Rapp

name: Blue Rodeo
comments: Country rock band formed in Toronto, Ontario

name: Ric Grech
comments: Born in Bordeaux, France. As a multi-instrumentalist, he was a ubiquitous figure in the rock world in the 1970s. He was also a popular session musician.

name: Herbert Kretzmer
comments: South African-born journalist and songwriter who has resided in London since the mid-1950s

name: Mitchell Parish
comments: Lyricist, who was born into a Jewish family in Lithuania that immigrated to the US before his first birthday. By the late 1920s Parish was a well-regarded Tin Pan Alley lyricist in New York City. Inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame in 1972 and winner of the Johnny Mercer Award award in 1986.

name: Horace Heidt
aliases: Horace Heidt and His Musical Knights
Horace Heidt and His Musical Knights - Vocal Chorus by "Heidtlites"
Horace Heidt and His Musical Knights - Vocal Chorus Heidt High Lights
Horace Heidt and His Musical Knights - Vocal Chorus Heidt's High Lights
comments: Pianist, big band leader, and radio and television personality

name: Marion Harris
comments: Harris was the first widely known white vocalist to sing blues and jazz songs.

name: Turner Layton
comments: Singer, pianist and composer born in Washington, D.C. In the early 1920s he wrote music for Broadway shows. By 1924 he began a successful career as a performer in England.

name: James Moreland
comments: Guitarist and singer/songwriter from Los Angeles, CA. He started with the Los Angeles punk band Mongrels in 1978, forming the Downers in 1980 (with David Roback and John Hoffs, the brother of Susanna Hoffs of the Bangles), and then initiating The Leaving Trains later that year.

name: American Gypsy
comments: Since 1963, this funk group has performed under diverse names such as Blue Morning, Orpheus and Pasadena Ghetto Orchestra. American Gypsy began club performances in Los Angeles in 1971, followed by a two-year tour of Spain. When the group settled in Amsterdam, The Netherlands in the early 70's, the line-up was: Joe Skeete (bass guitar), Michael Hamane (lead guitar), Lorenzo Mills (vocals), Richard James aka Ricardo James (drums), David Harrell (vocals, guitar, sax, flute) and Steve Clisby (vocals, keyboards). During their American period, individual members recorded sessions with many popular artists: Barry White The Byrds, Young Rascals, Frank Zappa, Jefferson Airplane, Dr. John and Santana.

name: Blue Weaver
comments: Welsh keyboard player, founding member of Amen Corner and briefly in Strawbs.  Weaver has also played in the Bee Gees backing band and appears on several of their albums.

name: Top of the Pops
comments: This is NOT a real artist or group, just an anonymous cover versions project cleverly and successfully using the name of the famous chart show that the BBC had neglected to trademark as a brand. Between 1968 and 1985, a total of some 1250 sound-alike versions of UK chart hits were included on ninety-two compilations (plus some editions with extra tracks) using the TotP monikers.

name: Zack Whyte
aliases: Smoke Jackson and His Red Onions
Zack Whyte and His Chocolate Beau Brummels

name: The Whitstein Brothers
comments: Country and gospel music duo of brothers, Robert (guitar) and Charles (mandolin).  They initially went by the professional name, The Whitstine Brothers, but reverted back to their given last name later in their career.  The duo ended with Robert's death in 2001.

name: Ivor Novello
comments: Welsh composer and actor in both silent films and on stage.  Novello was an early giant in British musical theatre as a composer and he also composed for film.

name: Lena Ford
comments: Lyricist.  Born in the United States as Lena Gilbert Brown, after divorcing her husband, Ford relocated to London with her mother and child, Walter, where she lived for some twenty years.  Ford and Walter were killed in a German air raid, becoming the first American fatalities in London in a German air raid.

name: Stanley Kirkby
comments: Baritone singer in several genres, Kirkby was a star performer in music halls, commanding large sums of money for the times.  Kirkby was also a prolific recording artist who recorded on numerous aliases as well as his given name.

name: Malcolm Martineau
comments: Scottish pianist, particularly known as an accompanist to singers

name: Captain Cardiac and The Coronaries
comments: Rock covers band from Los Angeles.

name: The Cowboy Church Sunday School
comments: In an attempt to sound like small children, adult vocals were speeded up for their one song. The vocals were performed by songwriter Stuart Hamblen's family.

name: David Pfeiffer
comments: Anonymous studio vocalist specialized in sound-alike covers for the US budget label Waldorf Music Hall.

name: Jimmy Savile
comments: Television personality known for his stint as presenter on "Top of the Pops" and "Jim'll Fix It.

name: Andy Parker [US]
comments: Western music performer, band leader and actor from Oklahoma

name: Margo Rey
comments: Singer-songwriter and actress who describes her music as "organica”, an unorthodox hybrid of pop music that is rooted in Jazz with deep ethno-rhythmic grooves, textural guitars, keys and lush vocals. Rey was born in Mexico and raised in the U.S.

name: Amy Adams [US2]
comments: Finalist on the third season of American Idol

name: Thomas Blug
comments: Guitarist, won the awards "Best German Pop and Rock Guitarist" in 1997 and "Stratplayer of the Year" in 2004.

name: Jay Whidden
aliases: Jay Whidden and His New Midnight Follies Band
comments: Songwriter, violinist and dance band bandleader with long stints in both the US and the UK

name: Tak Shindo
comments: Songwriter and musician  best remembered for his albums in the exotica genre. He often incorporated Japanese and other non-Western instruments in his music.

name: Mary Kay Place
comments: Actress, director, screen writer and singer.

name: Toby Beau
comments: Texas soft rock band formed in the early 1970s.

name: Mack Allen Smith
aliases: Mack Allen Smith and The Flames
comments: Rock 'n' roll and country singer and songwriter

name: Bam Margera
comments: Professional skateboarder, television and radio personality, actor and musician.

name: Francisco Domínguez
personal_name: Francisco José Domínguez de la Rosa

name: Los Rebeldes del Rock
comments: Rock 'n' roll group from Mexico City, active as a recording band between the late 1950s and mid 1960s with occasional live appearances since the mid 1970s.

name: Guillermo Tena
personal_name: Guillermo Américo Tena de la Rosa

name: Buddy Childers
comments: Trumpet player.  Childers initial fame came when he was hired at age 16 by Stan Kenton to play trumpet in his orchestra.

name: Leake County Revelers
comments: Country music string band from Mississippi that recorded for Columbia between 1927 and 1930.  Members of the group were Will Gilmer on fiddle. Dallas Jones on guitar and most lead vocals, R.O. Moseley on banjo and mandolin, and Jim Wolverton on banjo.

name: Leo Soileau
aliases: The Four Aces with Leo Soileau
Leo Soileau and His Three Aces
comments: Cajun music fiddler and singer. He was one of the most recorded Cajun artists in the 1930s and 1940s when record companies were not particularly interested in the music.

name: Dixon Brothers
comments: The Dixon Brothers were a country music duo. Members included Dorsey Murdock Dixon b. October 14, 1897 in Darlington, South Carolina d. April 18, 1968 in Plant City, Florida and Howard Dixon b. June 19, 1903 in Darlington, South Carolina d. March 24, 1951

name: Dorsey Dixon
comments: Country music singer, guitarist and songwriter from Darlington, South Carolina. He performed with his brother, Howard, as The Dixon Brothers.

name: Dick Brown
comments: Vocalist and night club entertainer born in Youngstown, Ohio. After his military service in World War II, he moved to New York City where he had his own radio show;  His musical director was Mac Ceppos, One of his guests was Duke Ellington. From 1948 to 1952 he and Kay Armen were the featured vocalists on the ABC radio network's popular quiz show, "Stop the Music" (emceed by Bert Parks). In 1957 he decided to become a cantor and entered a five year program of study at Hebrew Union College. After receiving his degree he taught history and music of the Bible and was a cantor and educational director  at temples in Coral Gables, Florida, South Bend, Indiana, Charlotte, North Carolina and Des Moines, Iowa.

name: Persephone's Bees
comments: Los Angeles-based pop/glam rock/punk group centered around Russian-born Angelina Moysov (vocals, keyboards) and Tom Ayres (guitar, bass, vocals).

name: Liv Maessen
comments: Pop singer from Melbourne, active from 1969 till 1974

name: Péter Tardos
comments: Journalist, composer, songwriter and comedian born in Berettyóújfalu

name: Tennyson Stephens
comments: Soul, funk and jazz pianist and songwriter

name: Clifford Greenwood
comments: Clifford Greenwood was an HMV staff conductor and conductor of the London Palladium Orchestra.

name: Herbie Flowers
comments: Bass and tuba player who became prominent performing with David Bowie, Elton John and Lou Reed

name: Clive Dunn
comments: Actor, comedian, artist and author best known for his role as Corporal Jones in the BBC comedy TV series 'Dad's Army'.

name: Sonny Lemaire
comments: Bass guitarist, singer and songwriter, best known as member of the band Exile

name: Norman Brooks
comments: Born in Montreal of Lebanese parents, brooks was a singer and actor. He played Al Jolson in the 1956 film "The Best Things in Life Are Free".

name: The Mello Larks
comments: Vocal group formed in 1946 when they sang with Tex Beneke and the Glenn Miller Orchestra. They disbanded in 1960. The original members were Ginny O'Connor, who married Henry Mancini in 1947, Tommy Hamm, Bob Smith and Jack Bierman.

name: Ramey Idriss
comments: Ramey Idriss was a composer, songwriter, musician and author. He received an Oscar nomination for "The Woody Woodpecker Song."

name: Stingray Green
comments: Power pop band from Minneapolis, Minnesota

name: OTT
comments: A short lived boys band of the late 1990s.

name: Don Wolf
comments: Jazz and pop songwriter, mainly in the 50s and 60s. Frequent collaborator with Ben Raleigh

name: The Jet Black's
comments: Foremost an instrumental group inspired by The Shadows and The Ventures, formed in São Paulo

name: Okay Monday
comments: Pop-rock group from Lille including Aurélien Gainetdinoff, Jérémy Cuvelier and Johnny Boom Golightly

name: Assisting Sorrow
comments: Melodic death metal band from Louisville, Kentucky

name: Neurosilence
comments: Melodic death band from Oslo, which changed its name to Pallid Threnody

name: Locomotive [CZ]
comments: Metal band from Český Krumlov, which plays a mixture of thrashcore and groove metal

name: Vladimirs
comments: Horror punk / metal band from Cincinnati, Ohio

name: Chuck Pyle
comments: Country/folk singer-songwriter nicknamed the Zen Cowboy

name: Juárez
comments: Folk rock band, who only released one album before disbanding

name: Coven, Pitrelli, O. Reilly
comments: Rock trio. CPR was active in 1992 only and the band published just one release. With John O. Reilly on drums.

name: Lou Berryman
comments: Songwriter and singer from Wisconsin, mostly of comic folk songs with her former husband.

name: Peter Berryman
comments: Songwriter and singer originally from Philadelphia, based in Wisconsin who most often writes and performs with his former wife

name: Marien Nicotine
comments: Musician, singer, ex-member of The Apers . Since then part of The Windowsill

name: Club de Soul
comments: Early house/dance outfit from Madrid, headed by Spandau Ballet fanatic Pedro Cortés. Among the members were a young DJ Dimas (Dimas Carbajo) and Fernando Rodríguez "Nanin".

name: Nils Perne
comments: Composer and songwriter from Uppsala. Later director of the Oscarsteatern on Kungsgatan in Stockholm.

name: Björn Forsell
comments: Opera singer and actor born in Stockholm

name: The Quarefellas
comments: Irish folk band from Perth, active in the 1970s

name: Howard Dixon
comments: Country and old time music fiddler and guitarist from Darlington, South Carolina

name: The Bon-Aires
comments: The Bon-Aires were a doo-wop vocal group from New Jersey. Members included George Lavatelli [lead], Mike Paladino [tenor], Dennis Diamond [tenor] and Scotty MacLerie [baritone].

name: Leo Breiten
comments: Entertainer, singer and lyricist born in Rosenheim.

name: Chuck Murphy
comments: Country boogie pianist and singer from Montgomery, Alabama

name: Billy Mata
aliases: Billy Mata and The Texas Tradition
comments: Country music and western swing singer and band leader from San Antonio, Texas.

name: Alan Lindgren
comments: Keyboardist, arranger, producer, studio and session musician

name: Clueless
comments: Eurodance act - Adam Marano, Gina Pincosy, Sebastian Simmich

name: Voices by the Sea
comments: Vocal ensemble from Virginia directed by Mandonia Porter Owens.

name: Frank Fontaine
comments: American stage, radio, film and television comedian, singer and actor

name: The Puppets
comments: Beat group from Preston, Lancashire, managed by Joe Meek.

name: Ed Snodderly
comments: Country singer, musician, song writer and actor from East Tennessee.

name: Secret Grief
comments: Pop punk/indie band from Michigan. Started as Tiger! Tiger!

name: Lawnmower
comments: Pop punk/alternative rock band from Michigan

name: Garnet Rogers
comments: Guitarist, singer and songwriter in the folk music tradition.

name: Rudy Smith
comments: Steel pan and steel drum player who plays jazz

name: Anese Hadeed
comments: Now based in London, Hadeed is a steel pan player.

name: Ali Tabatabaee
comments: Born in Tehran, then moved to California at the age of six

name: Willie "The Lion" Smith
aliases: Willie Smith (The Lion) and His Cubs
Willie (The Lion) Smith and His Orchestra
Willie "The Lion" Smith and His Washingtonian Jazz Cubs
personal_name: William Henry Joseph Bonaparte Bertholoff Smith
comments: Master traditional jazz and stride pianist.  Smith's birth father was Frank Bertholoff. who was Jewish, and Smith learned Hebrew.  Later in life, Smith was a cantor for a black Jewish congregation in Harlem.

name: Papa Doo Run Run
comments: Cover band from Cupertino, California, specializing in surf music

name: Tidal Waves
comments: Garage rock group from Roseville, Michigan, a suburb of Detroit. Two of the group's members were seniors at Roseville High School, and the three other members went to Roseville's Burton Junior High. The band opened for such national touring acts as The Animals and The Dave Clark Five at Detroit performances.

name: The Black Angels
comments: Psychedelic rock band from Austin, TX.

name: Psychic Ills
comments: Experimental & psychedelic rock band from New York City

name: Ivor Emmanuel
comments: Singer from Pontrhydyfen near Swansea.  After losing his family at an early age during World War II, Emmanuel worked in coal mining and steelmaking before moving to London and establishing a musical career.  He had West End theatre roles in Oklahoma!, South Pacific and The King and I, amongst other musicals, and gained roles in television and film.

name: Siân Hopkins
comments: Soprano singer from Cardiff, known mainly for her teenage performances on the television show Gwlad y Gan.  She now lives and performs in the Costa del Sol in Spain.

name: The Pontcanna Children's Choir
comments: A Cardiff-based choir specially established by Cliff Bunford for the chorus of the television show Gwlad y Gan and named for the TV studio from where the show was broadcast.  Boys were selected from the choir of Cathays High School and girls were selected from the choir of Canton High School.  They are shown in this photograph with Ivor Emmanuel.

name: Elmo Hope
comments: Bop/hard bop pianist, composer and arranger

name: Johnny Cooper [US]
comments: Rock 'n roll singer, active in the 1960s

name: Bill Erman
comments: Chicago coal and oil company owner, whose love was music. He started out writing songs, soon established his own publishing company, Venetia Music, and started and operated several record labels.

name: Nils Bertil Dahlander
comments: Drummer emigrating to the US in the late 1950s and becoming a sideman for jazz musicians like Chet Baker, Sonny Rollins, Lester Young and many more. Also recording in Scandinavia and Japan, both in his own rights and with local stars.

name: Brad Leali
comments: Jazz alto saxophonist and jazz educator from Denver, Colorado

name: Monte Carlo
comments: Born in Denmark as Hans von Holstein, Carlo came to the United States in 1906.  Thereafter he changed his name to Hans Carlo, but so began going by Monte Carlo.  He became a naturalized American citizen in 1914.  Carlo was composer of popular music, including for Broadway (for which he generally wrote lyrics as well as music).  He frequently wrote music with Alma Sanders, who became his  wife.

name: Richard W. Pascoe
comments: Lyricist and songwriter born in in Penzance, Cornwall, England.

name: Fredric Fradkin
comments: Violinist.  Fradkin was the Concertmaster between 1918 and 1920 for the Boston Symphony Orchestra.  He was fired for his support of unionizing the orchestra musicians.  He did only minimal concert work thereafter, but he was able to record throughout the 1920s.

name: Collin McLoughlin
comments: Producer, singer, and DJ from Bedford, New York

name: Diane Marino
comments: Jazz and pop vocalist and pianist

name: Pat Bergeson
comments: Jazz-influenced Nashville-based guitarist and harmonica player. He is a multi-genre session musician.

name: Giovani Giovani
aliases: I Giovani Giovani di Pino Donaggio
I Giovani, Giovani di Pino Donaggio

name: Carla Ulbrich
comments: Comical singer-songwriter and guitarist who describes herself as a "professional smart aleck." Ulbrich is originally from Clemson, South Carolina, and currently lives in New Jersey.

name: Pedro's Heavy Gentlemen
comments: "Studio band" found by Pedro Hietanen in the late 1970's. The line-up has changed often and lot of famous Finnish musicians have appeared on the albums.

name: Timothy Seaman
comments: Acoustic soloist who plays and teaches hammered dulcimer, a large collection of flutes and whistles, psalteries, mountain dulcimer and guitar. Most of his recordings have been done in collaboration with Virginia’s national and state parks and other agencies, representing their natural and historic themes.

name: Stuart Margolin
comments: Television actor, best known for playing "Angel" Martin in the NBC television series "The Rockford Files".  Margolin also worked as a musician in the late-1960s and has written songs.

name: Dave Goulder
comments: Singer, guitarist, dry stonewall builder, mountain climber, railway fireman, humorist, and composer.

name: Maj Britt Andersen
comments: Singer, often for children, and actress

name: Philip Kruse
comments: Bandleader, songwriter, producer and music publisher.

name: The Browne Sisters
comments: Folk group comprising sisters Diane, Pamela, and Laura . George Cavanaugh is their cousin.

name: Malcolm Lockyer
aliases: Malcolm Lockyer's Strict Tempo Music for Dancing
comments: Film composer and conductor. In his early years he developed an interest in dance and from here gathered an interest in music. At the age of nineteen he became a musician in the Royal Air Force and in 1944 joined the Buddy Featherstonhaugh Sextet.

name: Ivan Zagni
comments: UK-born guitarist, composer and arranger who moved to New Zealand in 1980, becoming the first Composer in Residence with the Auckland Philharmonia Orchestra (1989/90).

name: Tim Hinkley
comments: Hammond organist and pianist who has played as a session musician for artists such as Al Stewart, Alvin Lee, Joan Armatrading, Bad Company and Dr. Feelgood.

name: Jody Grind [GB]
comments: Progressive rock group who make two albums 1969-70 with different line-ups, Tim Hinkley being the only constant member.

name: Jack Blanchard
comments: Buffalo-born country music singer, keyboardist, guitarist and songwriter. He has recorded prolifically with his wife, Misty Morgan. In 2010, they were inducted into the Buffalo Music Hall of Fame.

name: Misty Morgan
comments: Buffalo-born country music singer, keyboardist and songwriter. She has recorded prolifically with her husband, Jack Blanchard . in 2010, they were inducted into the Buffalo Music Hall of Fame.

name: Gemini [GB]
comments: Pop music duo, comprised of twin brothers

name: ShyBoy
comments: Rock and pop singer-songwriter and producer

name: Brian Mohor
comments: Country pop singer and multi-instrumentalist based in Long Island, New York

name: April Moon
comments: Folk rock duo formerly from Canada but now based in Southport

name: Chinaza
comments: Jazz-pop vocalist; lead singer for Hattler

name: Lachy Doley
comments: Singer and keyboardist.  He typically plays a Hammond C3 organ.

name: Dan Random
comments: Pop rock singer and songwriter based in Atlanta, Georgia

name: Gisle Børge Styve
comments: Jazz/rock/pop pianist and vocalist. Most known as one of the pianist in the Norewegian TV show "Beat for beat" from 1999 to 2015.

name: Michael Monroe [US]
comments: Singer, guitarist and flautist based in Minnesota

name: The Supahip
comments: Pop duo of Carpenter and Mark Moldre

name: Slim Man
comments: Pop and jazz singer-songwriter and fretless bassist

name: The Mocks [DE]
comments: Retro band playing in the style of 1960s beat music

name: Willie Lester
comments: Disco and R&B songwriter and producer

name: Rodney Brown
comments: Disco and R&B songwriter, musician and producer

name: Bill Gurley
comments: Multi-instrumentalist (guitar, banjo, fiddle, mandolin,  Greek bouzouki, lap dulcimer, baritone uke) based in Virginia

name: Ann Robinson
comments: Celtic harp, hammered dulcimer, and bowed dulcimer player

name: Ricky Barnes
aliases: High Sheriff Ricky Barnes & The Hoot Owls

name: Del Noah & The Mt. Ararat Finks
Vocal Rush
comments: A cappella group from the Oakland School for the Arts, Oakland, California.

name: Home Free
comments: Male a cappella country music quintet who won the fourth season of "The Sing-Off". Line-up in 2022 is Foust, Austin Brown, Rob Lundquist, Adam Rupp and Adam Chance.

name: Princeton Footnotes
comments: Male a cappella group from Princeton University

name: Ten
comments: A cappella group based in Dallas, Texas

name: Element [US]
comments: Female a cappella group from New York City

name: VoicePlay
comments: Five-part male a cappella group from Orlando, Florida

name: The Filharmonic
comments: Filipino-American vocal group from Los Angeles, California

name: AcoUstiKats
comments: Male vocal ensemble from the University of Kentucky

name: C+C Music Factory
aliases: C&C Music Factory feat. Freedom Williams

name: Paul & Luke
comments: House music duo, Paolo Ortelli and Luca de Gregorio

name: Jacob Karlzon
comments: Jazz pianist and composer from Malmö

name: Lee Mead
comments: Musical actor, pop singer, songwriter. He was a contestant on the BBC talent series "Any Dream Will Do", a 2007 talent show-themed television series, which searched for a new, unknown lead to play Joseph in a West End revival of the Andrew Lloyd Webber musical musical Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat which he won.

name: Juicy J
comments: Rapper, songwriter and record producer from Memphis, Tennessee.

name: Maki Athanasiou
comments: Music producer, composer, and session guitarist

name: Jon Bellion
comments: Rapper, singer, songwriter and record producer

name: Frequency
comments: Music producer and DJ from New York

name: Aalias
comments: Music producer and musician from Cleveland, Ohio

name: The Irish Aires
comments: Irish folk music group from St. Louis, Missouri.

name: Steve Romanoff
comments: Folk Singer six and twelve-string guitar, five-string banjo - Maine

name: Thomas Fraser
comments: Scottish fisherman, singer and musician from the Shatland Isles.

name: Per Lofgren Trio
comments: Jazz trio, with Per himself originally from Sweden.

name: Roy Robinson
comments: Folk-rock and blues singer-songwriter and musician

name: Titanic
comments: Rock music band Formed in Germany

name: Bill Robbin
comments: Memphis guitar player, founder of The Bluejays

name: Dazzled Kid
comments: Singer and guitarist in the Amsterdam rock band Voicst.

name: Blaudzun
comments: Singer-songwriter Johannes Sigmond (Arnhem) played in various bands and projects before pursuing a solo career in 2006. He derived his alias from the Danish cyclist Verner Blaudzun, who won the bronze medal in the men's team time trial at the 1976 Montreal Olympics. Sigmond's break through to the general public in The Netherlands was his televised cover of "Shout" on the "De Wereld Draait Door Recordings" in 2011.

name: Hans Vandenburg
comments: Frontman and guitarist of Dutch band Gruppo Sportivo.

name: Jack Poels
comments: Singer, guitarist and harmonica player of the Dutch band Rowwen Hèze for which he has composed almost all the lyrics and music. His music is a mixture of folk, Tejano and accordion.

name: Marike Jager
comments: Dutch singer-songwriter, guitarist and television presenter born in Amersfoort.

name: Jaap Kwakman
comments: Guitarist and mandolinplayer, composer and lyricist. Founding member of the 3JS

name: Felix Maginn
comments: Singer and guitarist bornin Northern-Ireland, but living and working in The Netherlands for many years. He is the frontman of the band Moke.

name: Miss Montreal
comments: Dutch singer-songwriter and guitar player from Dedemsvaart.

name: Roosbeef
comments: Roosbeef is a Dutch band from Duiven around singer-songwriter Roos Rebergen.

name: TJR [Timothy John Ramirez]
comments: Rock & roll singer-songwriter, guitarist, and pianist

name: Pasi ja Pekka
comments: Duo consisting of the siblings Pasi and Pekka Saarnikko. Their only album (self-titled) was released in 1974.

name: Gene Kutch
comments: Jazz pianist and arranger from Trenton, New Jersey

name: Tom Baroco
comments: Pianist and music minister based in Florida

name: James I. Russell
comments: James Russell was an Irish-American vaudeville performer. He and his brother, John, performed together as the Russell Brothers, often dressing as women.

name: The Russell Brothers [US2]
comments: The Russell Brothers, John (1856-1925) and James (1859-1914), were Irish-American vaudeville performers. They were noted for their comedy routines, often dressing as women.

name: Tom Gilchrist
comments: Texas-based singer who performs swing, big band, jazz standards, Broadway and classic show tunes. He also owns Gilchrist & Company Real Estate brokerage firm.

name: Sinéad Lohan
comments: Singer/songwriter of folk and folk-inspired popular music, born in Cork. She left the music business after the birth of her second child in 2001.

name: Chano Domínguez
comments: Latin jazz pianist. He has become known for flamenco/jazz fusion.

name: Béla Sanders
aliases: Béla Sanders und sein großes Ball-Orchester
Béla Sanders und sein großes Ballorchester

name: Paradise Express
comments: Disco duo of Herb and Vi Ann Jimmerson.

name: Rique Franks
comments: Singer and voice actress from Toronto

name: The von Trapps
comments: Group comprising siblings Sofi, Melanie, Amanda, and August von Trapp, great-grandchildren of the Captain and Maria von Trapp.

name: Jack Hanna
comments: Director Emeritus of the Columbus Zoo and Aquarium in Ohio. Hanna has had several television shows, including Jack Hanna's Animal Adventures, Jack Hanna's Into the Wild, and Jack Hanna's Wild Countdown.

name: Don Pierce
comments: Don Pierce was a music industry executive, originally from Washington state.  He was with the Four Star label in the 1940s and was one of the founders of Starday in 1953. Later he became president of Starday. Pierce also took songwriter credit for several songs using the alias "William York." However, it is unlikely that he actually contributed to the writing of these songs.

name: Ken Clark
aliases: Ken Clark and The Merry Mountain Boys

name: Noel Gilmour
comments: Jazz pianist from Sydney, New South Wales

name: Gene Walton
comments: Country music singer, musician and songwriter from Jonesboro, Arkansas.

name: Trio Elf
comments: Alt rock-tinged jazz band: Gerwin Eisenhauer, Walter Lang & Sven Faller

name: Streetlife
comments: House music project covering disco hits

name: Nicklas Sample
comments: Jazz electric bassist and double bassist

name: U-Nam
comments: Soul/smooth jazz guitarist originally from France.

name: Eric Paslay
comments: Country music singer, from Abilene, Texas

name: Roger Williams [US2]
comments: Bluegrass dobro virtuoso born in Massachussetts

name: Kathleen Holeman
comments: Jazz/pop vocalist based in the Kansas City area; Director of Vocal Jazz and Jazz Piano at Missouri Western State University.

name: Bigband Brass & Fun
comments: Big band founded by music school director Bernd Kölmel together with his colleagues Peter Minet and Pirmin Ullrich

name: Margaret Bennett
comments: Scottish writer, folklorist, ethnologist, broadcaster and singer.

name: Adge Cutler
comments: Scrumpy and Western singer and songwriter, best known as the frontman of the comic folk band The Wurzels.

name: North Sea Gas
comments: Edinburgh based Scottish folk music band.

name: Gary Karr
comments: Double bassist particularly known for his solo performances.  Indeed, Karr claims to be the first double bassist to have a fulltime career performing as a soloist, although he also performs as a guest artist with orchestras.  He is also a music teacher.  Karr was born in the United States, but has become a citizen of Canada.

name: Tom Taylor
comments: Contemporary Christian singer/songwriter with a folk-country-rock sound

name: Jeremy Cays
comments: Composer, multi-instrumentalist, and producer based in Washington state

name: Tom Taylor [1]
comments: Guitarist and composer whose music is a hybrid of jazz, classical, rock and even a dash of blues and bluegrass.

name: Al Perkins [US2]
comments: Country and bluegrass steel guitarist and dobro player

name: Janet Klein
aliases: Janet Klein and Her Parlor Boys
comments: Singer and ukelele player from California.

name: Kunihiko Sugano
comments: Jazz pianist.  Name in native characters: 菅野邦彦.

name: Iris Kroes
comments: Singer-songwriter and harpist who was the winner of the second season of The Voice of Holland in 2011

name: Janet Tenaj
comments: Jazz vocalist, pianist, lyricist, songwriter and music educator.

name: Bob Kornegay
comments: Blues and R&B singer from New York City. Bob Kornegay recorded solo and was a member of several R&B vocal groups.

name: Jake Sinclair
comments: Producer and songwriter from Boise, Idaho

name: Sun Dragon
comments: Pop-psych duo whose entire career was limited to 1968.

name: Ken Campbell
comments: Scottish folk musician and singer-songwriter with a repertoire of traditional and contemporary folk style songs.

name: Chris Caswell
comments: Composer (including for film and television), lyricist, arranger and keyboardist

name: Tekelia Kelly
comments: Indie singer-songwriter who performs big band, jazz, standards, pop, and gospel music

name: Songs of Trees
comments: Acoustic project by songwriter Kevin Osborne

name: Riverboat Gamblers
comments: Punkrock band from Austin, Texas founded in 1997.

name: Let's Get Sushi and Not Pay
comments: All Acoustic Punk from New York City

name: Allegheny Jazz Quartet
comments: Jazz quartet put together for a five-day tour

name: Marjory Kennedy-Fraser
comments: Born in Perth to David Kennedy, a well-known Scottish singer, Marjory would, as a child, accompany him on piano in concert performances.  She married Alec Yule Fraser in 1887 but was widowed with two children in 1890 and made her living as a music teacher and lecturer.  With an interest in the Celtic Revival, she visited Eriskay in 1905.  There she witnessed many Gaelic folk songs endangered as a result of population decline and began a project to record and transcribe the music of the Hebrides.  In the following years, she visited many of the islands to the west of Scotland, recording the traditional songs with a wax cylinder phonograph.  She later arranged them for voice and piano, or sometimes for harp or clàrsach, publishing four volumes of songs.  For her contributions, she was awarded with a CBE and an honorary degree of Doctor of Music from the University of Edinburgh, to which she presented her archive of songs, including her original wax cylinders of recordings.

name: Kenneth MacLeod
comments: Rev. Dr. Kenneth MacLeod was a missionary and minister from the isle of Eigg, best known as a lyricist, translator, collector and restorer of folk songs, particularly his collaborations with Marjory Kennedy-Fraser.

name: Ford Dabney
comments: Musician, composer and band leader from Washington, D.C.

name: Hugh MacKay [GB]
comments: Singer from Dornoch specialising in songs of the Hebrides, who won a Gold Medal at the Mòd of 1912 and recorded for Pathé Actuelle and Parlophone.  He contracted polio, took up cycling as a method of regaining his health and became a tailor, taught music and played the flute, ultimately becoming a farmer in Essex.

name: Alfred James Forbes
comments: A piano tuner from a family of music dealers, whose trade took him as far as India, he was also a tenor singer associated with several Dundee choirs.

name: Aida Overton Walker
comments: Choreographer and vaudeville performer from New York City

name: The Virginians
comments: The name "The Virginians" was originally used by a small jazz subset of the Paul Whiteman Orchestra directed by Ross Gorman and later by ensembles made up of Victor house musicians.

name: Alasdair Gillies
comments: Born in Glasgow to Gaelic-speaking parents from Skye, Alasdair began singing in public at the age of seven and was soon taking part in music festivals and competing successfully in the Mòd.  He studied dentistry and became a house surgeon while continuing to perform and record.

name: Mairi MacArthur
comments: Singer with Gaelic roots in the Isle of Tiree and in mid-Argyll.  She gained widespread recognition when awarded Gold Medal at the National Mòd in 1965 and has since performed throughout Europe and North America.

name: Ishbel MacAskill
comments: Scottish singer and actress from the Isle of Lewis, known as the 'Gaelic diva'.

name: Tonn Nua
comments: Band from Oregon playing Scottish and Irish music.

name: Alison Helzer
comments: Tenor banjo player and folk singer from Eugene, Oregon.

name: Arthur Cormack
comments: Singer and musician from Portree, Isle of Skye.  Co-founder of Macmeanmna .

name: Hipnotic
comments: Deep house band/project of Ben Mitchell and Chris Fleming

name: Walter Lord
comments: Author, best known for his documentary-style non-fiction account 'A Night to Remember', about the sinking of the RMS Titanic. One time lyricist.

name: Saxie Dowell
comments: Saxophonist, jazz and pop music bandleader, singer and songwriter

name: Hack Swain
comments: Hammond organ and electric piano player and radio deejay based in Sarasota, Florida

name: May C. Hyers
comments: May. C. Hyers was a contralto from Tioga, Pennsylvania. She recorded cylinders for the Kansas City Talking Machine Company in 1898. Her repertoire spanned the range from opera to minstrel songs. She was the first African American woman to record.

name: Oni Logan
comments: Hard rock vocalist born in Buenos Aires, Argentina, who grew up in the US

name: John McCrae
comments: Canadian poet, physician, author, artist and soldier during World War I. He was a surgeon during this war and died of pneumonia with pneumococcus meningitis at the British General Hospital in Wimereux, France. A collection of his poetry "In Flanders Fields and Other Poems" (1918) was published after his death.

name: Bob Schneider
comments: Austin-based singer/songwriter known for his edgy blend of rock, folk, funk, and country styles.

name: Rita Rankin
comments: Singer from Mabou, Cape Breton, Nova Scotia.

name: Màiri Rankin
comments: Fiddle player and tutor from Mabou, Cape Breton, Nova Scotia

name: Ray Nichols
aliases: Ray Nichols and His Four Towers Orchestra

name: Jody Stecher
comments: Singer and musician.  Stecher plays cajun, bluegrass, Scottish folk music and blues.  He has also learned Hindustani classical music.  Stecher plays many string instruments, including Indian instruments.

name: Adrienne Young
comments: Charlottesville, Virginia-based singer, songwriter, and multi-instrumentalist

name: Blair Mackichan
comments: Actor, jazz musician, vocalist and songwriter.

name: Yoann Fréget
comments: Winner of the French edition of The Voice as part of Team Garou.

name: Joseph Hislop
comments: Scottish tenor singer, who gave concerts around the world and made a large number of recordings.  He sang at La Scala, Milan, the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, London, and the Opéra-Comique, Paris, as well as establishing a career in Denmark and Sweden, where he was made a Knight of the Dannebrog and a Knight of the Order of Vasa.  He was appointed Professor of Singing at the Royal Swedish Academy of Music, Stockholm.

name: Arthur Jordan
comments: A telegraphic engineer, who served in the Air Force before becoming a professional singer.  Jordan was from the Midlands and studied under Rutland Boughton, first as baritone and then as a tenor.  He joined the London School of Opera, and was one of the original members of the British National Opera Company.

name: Boyd Steven
comments: Scottish actress and mezzo soprano singer.

name: Frank Mullings
comments: A leading English tenor with Sir Thomas Beecham's Beecham Opera Company and its successor, the British National Opera Company, during the 1910s and 1920s.  He joined the staff of the Birmingham School of Music, teaching voice, working from 1927 to 1946. He also taught at the Royal Manchester College of Music from 1944 to 1949.

name: Glasgow Orpheus Choir
comments: Established in 1901 as the Toynbee Musical Association and founded as the Glasgow Orpheus Choir in 1906 under its conductor Sir Hugh Roberton, the choir was internationally acclaimed and set new standards.  It disbanded in 1951, on the retirement of its founder.

name: George Buck
comments: Leading preservationist of traditional jazz, jazz club owner in New Orleans and Drummer.  Buck founded both Jazzology and GHB .    Buck purchased entire labels as interest in traditional jazz and physical recordings waned because he wanted the music to be available.  At the time of his death, he also owned Circle, Southland, American Music, Black Swan, Audiophile, Progressive, and Solo Art.

name: Eden Brent
comments: Blues pianist and vocalist from Greenville, Mississippi.

name: Charlie Bush [US1]
comments: Highly regarded jazz guitarist in Gainsville, Florida until his death at the young age of 41.

name: Gabriel and The Angels
comments: Late 1950's - early 1960's doo-wop group from Camden, NJ.

name: The Gardenias
comments: R&B group from Georgia, active in the second half of the 1950s and the early 1960s

name: Rimshots [US]
comments: Disco-funk band who began life as the house band for All Platinum Records .

name: Gary Toms
comments: Disco-funk singer, arranger from New York.

name: Dick Smothers
comments: Actor, comedian, composer, musician and singer.

name: Drivin' n' Cryin'
comments: Hard rock band from Atlanta, Georgia

name: Brian Henneman
comments: Alt-country/roots rock musician from Festus, MO, best known as the frontman, key songwriter, singer and guitarist for The Bottle Rockets.

name: Don Herron
comments: Country rock singer-songwriter and multi-instrumentalist, born in Steubenville, OH.

name: Jewel Blanch
comments: Country singer, actress and independent music producer, who lived in the USA most of her life.

name: David Curtis
comments: Singer and guitarist, who released his first recordd at the age of 13.

name: Anni Piper
comments: Blues singer, song writer and bass player from Sydney. She moved to Cocoa Beach, Florida in 2014.

name: André  Ekyan
aliases: André Ekyan et son nouvel orchestre de danse
André Ekyan ses "sax Jumeaux" et son ensemble
comments: Swing jazz saxophonist, clarinetist, bandleader and composer.  Ekyan was known to play the saxophone and clarinet simultaneously.

name: Jim Goodwin [US1]
comments: Jazz cornetist and pianist from Portland, Oregon

name: Ham Carson
comments: Traditional and swing clarinetist based in Seattle

name: Kenny Roberts [US]
comments: Country music singer and yodeler born in Tennessee and raised in Massachusetts. Afterhe  completed his service in the Navy during World War II he organized and led a Philadelphia area western swing band, The Downhomers, and mentored a young Bill Haley who joined the Downhomers later in the 1940s.

name: Milt Shaw
aliases: Ralph Bennett and His Seven Aces (All Eleven of 'Em)
comments: Dance band bandleader, violinist and songwriter

name: David Tyack
comments: German born and Derbyshire raised musician and artist, active in Manchester on the Twisted Nerve label with several bands and as a solo performer.  He disappeared in 2002 after a particularly productive period; his body was found in 2004 in Corsica where he had apparently fallen to his death.

name: Francisco Carreras
comments: Composer (mainly of boleros, tangos and copla songs) and adapter of foreign songs to Spanish

name: Mark Hess
comments: Jazz musician who primarily plays traditional jazz and swing.  Hess is a multi-instrumentalist best known for piano.  He is based in San Antonio, Texas.

name: Luis Arcaraz
comments: Pianist, composer and arranger.  Arcaraz shied away from latin rhythms, playing mostly Mexican and American pop.

name: Harry Carter
aliases: Harry Carter The Rock N Roll Apache and The Rhythmaires

name: Jacques Denjean
comments: Pianist, organist, composer, arranger, orchestra leader behind several french pop singers of the 60s.

name: T-Baby Green
aliases: T-Baby Green on the Bon-Ton Show

name: Knud Jørgensen
comments: Jazz pianist born in Copenhagen but making Stockholm his home from the mid-1950s on

name: Mark Jordan [US]
comments: Pianist, organist, accordion player and singer-songwriter

name: Ann Rabson
comments: Blues vocalist, pianist and guitar player

name: Benny Strong
comments: Benny Strong was a Chicago-based band leader and singer. He was also known for his dancing and his impersonations of other singers including Bing Crosby, Rudy Vallee and Harry Richman. Early in her career, June Christy was a vocalist in his band.

name: Donald Davidson
aliases: Donald Davidson on His Hohner Harmonica
comments: A mouth organ player from Aberdeenshire, who recorded for the Beltona label between 1929 and 1939

name: Joe Kennedy [US1]
aliases: Joe Kennedy and His Rhythm Orchestra
comments: Relatively obscure pianist, singer and group leader active in the 1930s.

name: The Rattlers! [GB2]
comments: Rock n roll and rockabilly band

name: Jenny M. B. Currie
comments: Scottish soprano singer and pianist from mid-Argyll.  She won the Gold Medal at the Inverness Mòd in 1923.

name: Neil MacLean
comments: Tenor singer and prolific recording artist from mid-Argyll.  He undertook naval duties during World War I before attending Glasgow University.  He won the Gold Medal at the Glasgow Mòd of 1921.  From 1924 to 1930, he was Station Director at BBC Aberdeen where his programme "Sgeulachdan agus Oran" ("Stories and Songs") pioneered broadcasting in Gaelic.

name: Nat Brandwynne
aliases: Nat Brandwynne and His Stork Club Orchestra
Nat Brandwynne and The Stork Club Orchestra
comments: Pianist, bandleader and conductor born in New York City. In the 1930s he played with Eddy Duchin and Leo Reisman. In the 1950s he conducted the orchestra at Caesar's Palace in Las Vegas.

name: Florence MacBride
comments: Violinist born in Glasgow. One of the first female professional fiddlers in Scotland.

name: Pippo Franco
comments: Actor, comedian, television presenter and singer

name: The Ponce Sisters
comments: Vocal duo consisting of sisters, Ethel Ponce (1907-1989) and Dorothea "Dobbie" Ponce (1909-2000). In 1925 they became the first female duo to appear on national network radio. They also appeared on the vaudeville stage and recorded  in the 1920s and 1930s.

name: Phil Ponce
comments: Composer, author, publisher, radio executive, and music entrepreneur.

name: Sydney MacEwan
comments: A tenor singer and priest from Glasgow.

name: Kirkintilloch Junior Choir
comments: Founded in 1938 by Rev. John MacPherson.  After his death, Meta MacPherson, his wife, became leader until the choir was disbanded in 1968.  During its lifetime, the choir appeared regularly on the radio and at concerts, including foreign tours. The choir also recorded several discs for Parlophone.

name: Eddie Leonard
comments: Vaudeville performer and songwriter from Richmond, Virginia who often appeared in blackface. He was a professional baseball player with the Baltimore Orioles before he changed his name and started his show business career by joining a minstrel show. He also appeared in a few motion pictures.

name: Da Capo [FR]
comments: Band created in 1997 by the Paugam brothers, Alexandre & Nicolas Paugam.

name: Little Fish
comments: Bilbao based composer, guitarist, singer, producer and sound engineer. Not to be confused with a UK band of the same name

name: The Classmates
comments: Anonymous studio band specialized in sound-alike covers for the Nashville-based Hit Records and Top Pop Hits labels.

name: The Fantastics [US1]
comments: Anonymous studio band specialized in sound-alike covers for the Nashville-based Hit Records and Top Pop Hits labels.

name: The Norfolk Orch.
comments: Instrumental unit of the band Norfolk.

name: Tony Strong
comments: Soul singer based in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania

name: The Conspirators
comments: British folk-rock band: Darrell Banner, Genevieve Parker, John Gillies, Laura Goodacre, Nathan Reeve.

name: Edwin Clay
comments: Actor and singer, who played Gremio in the 1948 Broadway musical Kiss Me Kate .

name: Charles Wood [US1]
comments: Singer and Broadway actor in the 1940s and 1950s. He played the part of Hortensio in the 1948 Broadway musical Kiss Me Kate .

name: George Britton
comments: Beginning his professional career as an operatic bass-baritone, he eventually went on to become a folk singer and guitarist.

name: Helena Bliss
comments: Operatic soprano. She also performed with light opera companies and in stage musicals.

name: Larry Blyden
comments: Stage and television actor. He is also remembered as the host of "What's My Line?" and other game shows.

name: Ed Kenney
comments: Singer-actor from Hawaii best known for the role of "Wang Ta" in the original Broadway production of Flower Drum Song

name: Nancy Kwan
comments: Actress. She gained great popularity early in her career with her movie roles in "The World of Suzy Wong" and "Flower Drum Song".

name: James Shigeta
comments: Hawaiian-born singer-actor. After his service in the Korean War, he had a singing career in Japan. Shigeta returned to the US in the late 1950s and became better known for his acting roles. Birth & death dates from Discogs

name: Jack Soo
comments: Actor. He is best remembered for his role as Detective Yemana on the television series "Barney Miller".

name: Daniel Evans [GB1]
comments: Singer from London who was a finalist in the fifth series of the X Factor in the UK. He is now based in Valencia, Spain.

name: Frances Burnett
comments: Soul singer, active as recording artist at the end of the 1950s and the beginning of the 1960s

name: Black Grape
comments: Rock band, who reunited briefly in 2010 and reformed in 2015

name: Floyd Cramer
aliases: Floyd Cramer at the Piano with Instrumental Accompaniment
Floyd Cramer & The Keyboard Kick Band
comments: Pianist who popularized the slip note style. Cramer was inducted into both the Country Music Hall of Fame and the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame's sideman category in 2003.

name: Jo Stafford
aliases: Jo Stafford and Her V-Disc Boys
Jo Stafford and Her V-Disc Play Boys

name: Dick Van Dyke
comments: Comedian, stage, screen and television actor, producer, writer and occasional vocalist

name: Enid Mosier
aliases: Enid Mosier and Her Trinidad Steel Band

name: Art Jarrett
comments: Singer, actor and bandleader born in Brooklyn, New York

name: Hoyt Axton
aliases: Hoyt Axton & The Hollywood Living Room Band
Hoyt Axton with The Billy Bible Blues Band
comments: Country and folk singer, songwriter and actor.

name: Orgy
comments: Electronic rock band from Los Angeles, California, formed in 1996.

name: Vernon Duke
comments: Name in Russian: Владимир Александрович Дукельский.  Duke was born of nobility in Belarus at a time when it was part of the Russian Empire.  Duke moved to the United States in 1929 and became a citizen in 1939.  He was a songwriter and composer. Inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame in 1970

name: Alfred Drake
aliases: Alfred Drake & The Kismet Original Broadway Cast

name: Aida Ward
comments: Nightclub, stage and radio singer in the 1920s and 1930s .

name: Hot Tuna
comments: Blues-rock band, formed in 1969 as a spin-off of Jefferson Airplane.

name: Jimmy Work
aliases: Jimmy Work and His Border Boys
Jimmy Work and His Tennessee Border Boys

name: The Sandpipers [US2]
comments: Easy listening trio. Singing in English, Spanish, French, Italian, Portuguese and Tagalog, they had seven separate album entries in the Billboard 200 from 1966-1970 and over a dozen charted singles.

name: Sonya Hunter
comments: San Francisco-based folk-pop singer and songwriter

name: Mushroom [US]
comments: Psychedelic rock band consisting of an "ever-shifting collective" of friends and acquaintances in the San Francisco Bay area

name: Tom Stevens
comments: Singer-songwriter, bassist and guitarist, born and raised in Elkhart, Indiana

name: Jonah Jones
aliases: Jonah Jones and His Latin Rhythm
Jonah Jones - The Quartet with Trombone

name: Big in Iowa
comments: Country Rock from Cincinatti headed by Bob Burns and Ken Glidewell

name: Shane Faubert
comments: Alt rock/folk rock singer and multi-instrumentalist.

name: Tom Rapp
comments: Singer and songwriter who led Pearls Before Swine, the influential psychedelic folk rock group of the 1960s and 1970s. He later practiced as a civil rights lawyer.

name: Map of Wyoming
comments: Americana project based in the San Francisco area.

name: Chris Cacavas
aliases: Chris Cacavas & The Slivers of Hope
comments: Songwriter, keyboard player and singer, born in Tucson, AZ. These days, he lives near Karlsruhe in southwestern Germany.

name: The Walkabouts
comments: Folk rock group from Seattle, WA. They became the first non-grunge artists on Sub Pop Records. Their music is described as dark, haunting, and elegiac, blending the storytelling traditions of American roots music with the excitement of rock'n'roll.

name: Eric Ambel
comments: Guitarist, songwriter and record producer from Illinois. He has also recorded as "Gringoman," where he plays all the instruments.

name: Mike Altman
comments: Altman is a movie director/producer/cinematographer and an author (under the pseudonym, Michael Barleycorn). His father, Robert Altman, also a movie director, commissioned Johnny Mandel to compose a song for the character Private Seidman in the 1970 movie M*A*S*H, stipulating that it should be called "Suicide Is Painless" and that it had to be the "stupidest song ever written".  Robert Altman tried writing a lyric himself but couldn't write "anything nearly as stupid as what we need" and gave the task to Mike, then aged 14.  Mike wrote the words "in five minutes", to which Mandel later added the melody.  In a 1980s interview, Robert Altman said that while he made $70,000 for directing the movie, Mike had earned more than $1 million in royalties for co-writing the song.

name: Ghosthouse
comments: Alt rock band from Los Angeles

name: Mountain Village Jazzmen
comments: Traditional/swing jazz group based in Hamburg

name: Shindu
comments: Dance act from Ghent: DJ Static, DJ Greedy & singer Chibi.

name: Sarah Brown
comments: Austin based blues bassist, singer and songwriter. She was part of Dave Alvin's all-female backup band The Guilty Women .

name: Tom Goux
comments: Seafaring musicologist, educator and instrumentalist from Massachusetts.

name: Kurt Hugo Schneider
comments: Video editor, musician, singer and songwriter

name: Against the Current
comments: Pop rock band from Poughkeepsie, New York

name: Konosuke Saijo
aliases: Kōnosuke Saijō and His Bossa Nova Quintet

name: Truly Smith
comments: Singer, who was signed to the Decca label when she was just 16 years of age. Her short-lived career lasted only 2 years: from 1966 till 1967.

name: Ed Saindon
comments: Jazz vibraphonist of the "four mallet school".  Saindon is a professor at Berklee College of Music where he has taught since 1976.

name: Jabbo Smith
aliases: Jabbo Smith and His Rhythm Aces
Jabbo Smith and His Rhythm Aces (Four Aces and the Joker)
comments: Hot jazz trumpeter and occasional singer

name: Joan Diener
comments: Actress and singer. She is largely remembered for her roles in the stage productions of "Man of La Mancha" and "Kismet".

name: Patricia Dunn
comments: Stage actress and dancer, who played the part of 2nd Princess of Ababu in the 1953 musical production Kismet .

name: Bonnie Evans
comments: Actress-dancer known for her parts in the movies "The Ladies Man" (1961), "The Astral Factor" (1978) and "Take Me, Love Me" (1970).

name: Mark Wilder
comments: Actor - born in Naples, Italy - of the stage and movies known for his parts in Funny Girl (1968) and Gentlemen Prefer Blondes (1953).

name: Ann Blyth
comments: Actress and singer born in Mount Kisco, New York. Her movie roles included appearances in "Mildred Pierce", The Great Caruso , One Minute to Zero , "Kismet" and "The Helen Morgan Story".

name: Gloria Grahame
comments: Actress; she won an Oscar for best supporting actress in "The Bad and the Beautiful" (1952)

name: Barry Kelley
comments: Actor. Often playing character roles, he was a fixture on the stage and later in television.

name: Hajime Yoshizawa
comments: Crossover jazz musician, pianist and keyboard player part of a Japanese renaissance in jazz viewed through the eyes of modern dance music, post London acid jazz, often termed 'nu-jazz'

name: Tori Kelly
comments: Singer and songwriter active in pop and Christian music

name: Laudibus
comments: The National Youth Chamber Choir of Great Britain, hailed by audiences and critics as one of the finest chamber choirs in the world.  The choir has acquired a reputation for the breadth of its programming and its dynamic and exciting performances. The members of Laudibus are chosen by audition from the 130-strong National Youth Choir of Great Britain.  Mike Brewer is the Choir Master.

name: Hugh Roberton
comments: Sir Hugh Roberton was a composer and choir master from Glasgow.

name: Don Stiernberg
comments: Jazz mandolin player who learned how to play in his teens from Jethro Burns .  Stiernberg is a longtime resident of Chicago.

name: The Carstairs
comments: Male vocal soul group from Detroit. The Carstairs achieved no significant success in their native country, but were huge in the UK thanks to the Northern Soul scene.

name: The Rivet Gang
comments: Bluegrass string band from New Mexico.

name: Vaughan Happy Two
comments: The Vaughan Happy Two was a vocal duet consisting of Cullie G. Wilson [tenor lead vocal] and Arthur B. Sebren [baritone vocal].

name: George Pastell
comments: Cyprus-born character actor often cast as a Middle Eastern villain.

name: Leon Thau
comments: Actor, producer and director born in Palestine

name: Randall Duk Kim
comments: Hawaiian born stage and film actor

name: The Knightsbridge Strings
comments: England's answer to Germany's 101 Strings Orchestra

name: The Strikes
comments: Rock 'n' roll band from east Texas

name: Richard Boone [US2]
comments: Actor who starred in over fifty films and was notable for his roles in Westerns

name: Robert Merrill
comments: Operatic baritone. He was well-known to the general public, making frequent appearances on radio and television.

name: Regina Resnick
comments: Operatic mezzo-soprano. She was a longtime principal at the Metropolitan Opera.

name: Ian Wallace
comments: Scottish operatic baritone and actor. He often performed comic roles.

name: Tamba Trio
comments: Bossa jazz ensemble formed by pianist Luiz Eça, flutist Bebeto (Castilho) and drummer Hélcio (Milito)

name: Mastema
comments: Raw Black Metal band from Noyers-Missy, Normandy.

name: David Atkinson
comments: Operatic baritone. He also had many roles in musicals throughout the 1950s and 1960s.

name: David Morris
comments: Broadway actor and singer from the 1930s t0 1950s.

name: Joseph Buloff
comments: Lithuanian-born actor. He was a fixture in Yiddish theater and on Broadway.

name: Ralph Riggs
comments: Actor. performer, designer and choreographer born in St. Paul, Minnesota.

name: Rod Steiger
comments: Actor. He is remembered for his roles in the movies "On the Waterfront", "The Pawnbroker", "Oklahoma", "Doctor Zhivago", "Waterloo" and "In the Heat of the Night", among others.

name: The Narrative
comments: Indie rock band from Long Island, New York

name: Christine Ebersole
comments: Singer-actress. She has had many appearances in television sitcoms. Her stage musical roles have earned her two Tony awards ("42nd Street", "Grey Gardens").

name: Eva Tanguay
comments: Singer-actress. She began in stage musicals and went on to a long career in vaudeville.
